newsitem.title: UK: Be Prince Charles's neighbour for $7.5 million?.
newsitem.headline: Be Prince Charles's neighbour for $7.5 million?.

text.p: House hunters looking for a better neighbourhood can now, for a price, move next door to the heir to the British throne.
The owners of the 1,400-acre (560-hectare) Estcourt Park bordering Prince Charles's Highgrove home put their estate up for sale on Wednesday for five million pounds ($7.5 million).
A royal spokeswoman refused to comment on speculation that the prince might buy the property himself.
An imposing Georgian manor house on the estate near Tetbury, Gloucestershire, 100 miles (150 km) west of London, was demolished in 1964.
But there is planning permission for a 1.5 million pound ($2.25 million) nine-bedroom chateau-style replacement.
The manor has been the home of the Estcourt family since 1303 and comes complete with a swan lake, stables and woodland.
The last surviving member of the family, reclusive bachelor Desmond Sotheron Estcourt, has no heirs and has been forced to sell because he needs the money.
"It is tragic for me but what is the good of whining. We all have our trials," Estcourt said. "I am hating all this - my family has been here 700 years."

Desmond inherited the estate from his father Thomas in 1961. Six rented cottages remain, along with an imposing gate and a tree-lined drive which was used in the BBC television drama "Pride and Prejudice".
